title: Self-Supervised Time-to-Event Modeling with Structured Medical Records. (arXiv:2301.03150v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)
abstract: Time-to-event (TTE) models are used in medicine and other fields for estimating the probability distribution of the time until a specific event occurs. TTE models provide many advantages over classification using fixed time horizons, including naturally handling censored observations, but require more parameters and are challenging to train in settings with limited labeled data. Existing approaches, e.g. proportional hazards or accelerated failure time, employ distributional assumptions to reduce parameters but are vulnerable to model misspecification. In this work, we address these challenges with MOTOR (Many Outcome Time Oriented Representations), a self-supervised model that leverages temporal structure found in collections of timestamped events in electronic health records (EHR) and health insurance claims. MOTOR uses a TTE pretraining objective that predicts the probability distribution of times when events occur, making it well-suited to transfer learning for medical prediction t

Title: Self-Supervised Time-to-Event Modeling with Structured Medical Records. (arXiv:2301.03150v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)
Abstract: Time-to-event (TTE) models are used in medicine and other fields for estimating the probability distribution of the time until a specific event occurs. TTE models provide many advantages over classification using fixed time horizons, including naturally handling censored observations, but require more parameters and are challenging to train in settings with limited labeled data. Existing approaches, e.g. proportional hazards or accelerated failure time, employ distributional assumptions to reduce parameters but are vulnerable to model misspecification. In this work, we address these challenges with MOTOR (Many Outcome Time Oriented Representations), a self-supervised model that leverages temporal structure found in collections of timestamped events in electronic health records (EHR) and health insurance claims. MOTOR uses a TTE pretraining objective that predicts the probability distribution of times when events occur, making it well-suited to transfer learning for medical prediction t
translated_abstract: 时间至事件（TTE）模型在医学和其他领域用于估计发生特定事件的时间的概率分布。TTE模型相对于使用固定时间范围的分类具有许多优点，包括自然处理被屏蔽的观测值，但需要更多参数，而在有限标记数据的情况下训练具有挑战性。现有方法（例如比例风险或加速失效时间）使用分布假设来减少参数，但容易出现模型失配。本研究使用MOTOR(Many Outcome Time Oriented Representations)解决这些挑战，MOTOR是一种自监督模型，利用电子医疗记录（EHR）和健康保险索赔中时间戳事件的集合中发现的时间结构。MOTOR使用TTE预训练目标，预测事件发生时的时间概率分布，因此非常适合于医学预测的转移学习。
tldr: 本研究提出了一种自监督模型MOTOR，利用电子医疗记录和健康保险索赔中的时间戳事件的时间结构。它使用时间至事件（TTE）预训练目标进行训练，可以帮助医学预测的转移学习。
en_tdlr: This paper proposes a self-supervised model, MOTOR, which leverages temporal structure found in collections of timestamped events in electronic health records and health insurance claims. It uses the time-to-event (TTE) pretraining objective for training, making it well-suited to transfer learning for medical prediction.
